titleproper.value: Guide to Maurice Isserman Research Files <num>TAM 239</num>

author.value: Collection processed by Katja Vehlow; Entered into the Archivist's Toolkit by John D. Bence

publisher.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

addressline: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

creation.value: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace <date>2018-05-08T15:51:32</date>

corpname.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

abstract.value: Maurice Isserman is an historian and author of <emph render="italic">The Other American: The Life of Michael Harrington</emph> (2000), and several other books relating to the history of the American left. The bulk of the collection contains interview transcripts, topical files, newspaper clippings and FBI files related to Isserman's research on Michael Harrington. Prominent interviewees include: William F. Buckley, Lewis Coser, Norman Dorsen, Hal Draper, Harry Fleischman, John K. Galbraith, Herbert Gans, Michael Harrington (there are also two interviews of Harrington conducted by others), his wife Stephanie Harrington, Irving Howe, Irving Kristol, David McReynolds, Jack Newfield, Victor Reuther, Eugene Rostow, Andre Schiffrin, Stanley Sheinbaum, and Diana Trilling. The collection also contains several files related to Isserman's research on American Communism between 1977 and 1980.

p.value: Identification of item, date; Maurice Isserman Research Files; TAM 239; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
Materials were donated by Maurice Isserman in 2000 and 2016. The accession numbers related to these gifts are 2000.024 and 2016.060.

Michael Harrington (1928-1989), is best known as the author of <emph render="italic">The Other America: Poverty in the United States</emph> (1962), and as the founder and leader of the Democratic Socialist Organizing Committee, which later became the Democratic Socialists of America (U.S. affiliate of the Socialist International). He also taught political science at Queens College, part of the City University of New York, and continued to write, lecture and travel widely until his death from cancer in 1989. Among his many books were two autobiographical works, <title render="italic">Taking Sides: The Education of a Militant Mind</title>(1985) and <title render="italic">The Long-Distance Runner : An Autobiography</title>(1987), <title render="italic">The New American Poverty</title>(1984), <title render="italic">The Politics at God's Funeral: The Spiritual Crisis of Western Civilization</title>(1985), and <title render="italic">Socialism : Past and Future</title>(1989).

The collection contains several files related to Isserman's research on American Communism during World War II. These files date from 1977 to 1980 and include photocopies of Communist Party meetings between 1935 and 1940 and records related to the Office of Strategic Services (OSS) and the Communist Party. They also contain correspondence with Joe Clark, letters related to Isserman's research on Earl Browder, and transcript of an oral history interview with Steve Nelson.
